definition: The skin and its accessory structures, including hair, nails, sensory receptors, arrector pili muscles, and glands.
The largest organ of the body by weight, composed of the epidermis and dermis layers.
The outer layer of the skin made up of stratified squamous epithelium; it lacks blood vessels.
The inner layer of the skin consisting of connective tissue with collagen and elastic fibers, smooth muscle, nervous tissue, and blood vessels.
A layer beneath the skin composed of areolar and adipose tissue that binds the skin to underlying organs.
The deepest layer of the epidermis containing dividing cells that give rise to new keratinocytes.
The process by which epidermal cells fill with keratin protein, harden, and die as they move toward the skin surface.
The outermost layer of the epidermis composed of dead, flattened, keratinized cells.
Specialized cells in the epidermis that produce the pigment melanin.
A dark pigment that provides skin color and absorbs ultraviolet radiation to protect underlying cells.
Phagocytic cells in the epidermis that help protect the skin from pathogens by initiating immune responses.
Cells in the stratum basale that respond to light touch sensations.
Projections of the dermis that interlock with the epidermis, increasing surface area for nutrient exchange and forming fingerprints.
A tubelike depression in the skin where hair develops from epidermal stem cells.
Holocrine glands associated with hair follicles that secrete sebum to keep hair and skin soft and waterproof.
An oily mixture of fatty material and cellular debris produced by sebaceous glands.
Exocrine glands in the skin that secrete sweat to help regulate body temperature and excrete waste.
The most numerous sweat glands that respond to elevated body temperature and secrete a watery sweat.
Glands that become active at puberty and secrete sweat during emotional stress, pain, or sexual arousal.
Modified apocrine sweat glands in the ear canal that secrete cerumen (ear wax).
Modified sweat glands in the breasts that secrete milk during pregnancy and lactation.
A bundle of smooth muscle fibers attached to each hair follicle that contracts to cause goosebumps.
A protective covering on the ends of fingers and toes composed of keratinized epidermal cells.
The whitish, half-moon-shaped region at the base of the nail plate where cell division occurs.
A thickened area of skin that forms in response to repeated friction or pressure.
An inherited condition characterized by a lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.
A bluish discoloration of the skin resulting from low oxygen concentration in the blood.
The medical specialty focused on diagnosing and treating skin disorders.
A process initiated in the skin where sunlight converts a precursor molecule into inactive vitamin D, later activated by the liver and kidneys.
An abnormally high body temperature, often caused by prolonged exposure to heat.
An abnormally low body temperature resulting from prolonged exposure to cold.
A tissue response to injury or stress, characterized by redness, heat, swelling, and pain.
New connective tissue and microscopic blood vessels that form on the surfaces of a wound during the healing process.
A burn affecting only the epidermis, causing redness and pain without blistering.
A burn damaging the epidermis and part of the dermis, leading to blistering and possible scarring.
A severe burn destroying the epidermis, dermis, and accessory structures, often requiring skin grafts.
A method used to estimate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns.
An injury to the skin and underlying tissue resulting from prolonged pressure on the skin.
A tough, fibrous protein accumulating in epidermal cells during keratinization, making the skin waterproof.
Specialized junctions that fasten cells together in strong sheets within the epidermis.
A translucent layer of the epidermis found only in thick skin areas like the palms and soles.
A brownish-black pigment contributing to dark hair and skin color.
A reddish-yellow pigment found in certain areas like the lips and responsible for red hair.
The portion of hair that extends above the skin surface, composed of dead, keratinized cells.
A projection of connective tissue at the base of the hair follicle containing blood vessels that nourish growing hair.
A type of skin cancer originating from epithelial cells.
A type of skin cancer arising from melanocytes, often more serious due to its ability to spread.
A thin, nonliving layer anchoring the epidermis to the dermis.
The papillary layer (areolar connective tissue) and the reticular layer (dense irregular connective tissue) of the dermis.
The region of dividing cells in the hair bulb responsible for hair growth.
A skin condition resulting from excess sebum secretion clogging sebaceous glands, leading to inflammation.
Ear wax produced by ceruminous glands, helping to prevent entry of foreign substances into the ear canal.
Protection, sensation, vitamin D synthesis, body temperature regulation, and excretion.
Pigmented spots on the skin due to oxidation of fats in secretory cells, common in aging skin.
A fluid composed mainly of water and salts, secreted by sweat glands to help cool the body and excrete waste.
Hair loss resulting from genetics, hormonal changes, medical conditions, or aging.
The raised areas on the skin caused by contraction of arrector pili muscles attached to hair follicles.
